conclusion: Need to determine if the particle's motion direction from 2 to 3 seconds is the same as or opposite to the positive direction.
Understanding a velocity-time graph: x-axis is time, y-axis is velocity, positive direction is upwards, negative is downwards.
From 0 to 1 second, the velocity is constant at 2 m/s.
At 1 second, velocity starts decreasing linearly until it reaches 0 m/s at 2 seconds.
From 2 to 3 seconds, velocity becomes negative and decreases to -2 m/s.
From 2 to 3 seconds, negative velocity means motion is opposite to the positive direction.
Velocity is a vector quantity; its sign indicates the direction of motion relative to the positive direction.
Positive velocity indicates moving in the positive direction; negative velocity indicates moving in the negative direction.
Since velocity is negative from 2 to 3 seconds, the particle is moving opposite to the positive direction.
Red line from 2 to 3 seconds indicates the part of the graph where velocity is negative.
Recognizing that velocity's sign indicates the direction of motion; negative velocity means opposite direction.
0 to 1 s: velocity = 2 m/s (positive direction); 1 to 2 s: velocity decreases from 2 m/s to 0 m/s; 2 to 3 s: velocity from 0 m/s to -2 m/s (negative direction).
At t=2s, the particle changes its direction of motion from positive to negative.
From 2 to 3 seconds, the particle is moving in the opposite direction to the defined positive direction.
Considering acceleration: slope of the velocity-time graph.
From 0 to 1 s: slope = 0 (constant velocity); From 1 to 2 s: negative slope (decreasing velocity); From 2 to 3 s: negative slope (velocity becoming more negative).
Acceleration is about the change in velocity, not directly about the direction of motion.
For direction of motion, velocity sign is what matters. From 2 to 3 seconds, negative velocity means motion opposite to the positive direction.
Final answer: motion is opposite to the defined positive direction.
